urn:contentItem:6D3H-RM11-DY7R-R3V6-00000-00New Remote Sensing Study Results from Wuhan University Described (FD-Net: A Single-Stage Fire Detection Framework for Remote Sensing in Complex Environments)2024-10-02T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:23:37ZLexisNexisTECHNOLOGY - REMOTE SENSINGNew Remote Sensing Study Results from Wuhan University Described (FD-Net: A Single-Stage Fire Detection Framework for Remote Sensing in Complex Environments)


2024 OCT 02 (NewsRx) -- By a News Reporter-Staff News Editor at Tech Daily News -- Research findings on remote sensing are discussed in a new report. According to news reporting originating from Wuhan, People's Republic of China, by NewsRx correspondents, research stated, "Fire detection is crucial due to the exorbitant annual toll on both human lives and the economy resulting from fire-related incidents."


Funders for this research include National Natural Science Foundation of China.
The news correspondents obtained a quote from the research from Wuhan University: "To enhance forest fire detection in complex environments, we propose a new algorithm called FD-Net for various environments. Firstly, to improve detection performance, we introduce a Fire Attention (FA) mechanism that utilizes the position information from feature maps. Secondly, to prevent geometric distortion during image cropping, we propose a Three-Scale Pooling (TSP) module. Lastly, we fine-tune the YOLOv5 network and incorporate a new Fire Fusion (FF) module to enhance the network's precision in identifying fire targets."
According to the news reporters, the research concluded: "Through qualitative and quantitative comparisons, we found that FD-Net outperforms current state-of-the-art algorithms in performance on both fire and fire-and-smoke datasets. This further demonstrates FD-Net's effectiveness for application in fire detection."
For more information on this research see: FD-Net: A Single-Stage Fire Detection Framework for Remote Sensing in Complex Environments. Remote Sensing, 2024,16(18). (Remote Sensing - http://www.mdpi.com/journal/remotesensing/). The publisher for Remote Sensing is MDPI AG.
A free version of this journal article is available at https://doi.org/10.3390/rs16183382.
Our news editors report that more information may be obtained by contacting Jianye Yuan, Electronic Information School, Wuhan University, Wuhan 473072, People's Republic of China. Additional authors for this research include Haofei Wang, Minghao Li, Xiaohan Wang, Weiwei Song, Song Li, Wei Gong.
Keywords for this news article include: Wuhan University, Wuhan, People's Republic of China, Asia, Remote Sensing, Technology.
Our reports deliver fact-based news of research and discoveries from around the world. Copyright 2024, NewsRx LLC

urn:contentItem:6FN7-K5W3-RRJJ-V4VX-00000-00Russian General Killed in Car Bomb; Trump Rebukes Putin After Deadly Attack on Ukraine; Mourners Remember the Life & Legacy of Francis; Pope`s Legacy & Funeral Services Details; Teen Accused of Starting Massive NJ Wildfire; Harry & Meghan Spread Warning for Kids Online; The Scoop on the Yogurt Industry & Changing Policy; Vlad`s Top Five Ben Affleck Movies; Sharing The Stories Of Those Lost In History, CBS2025-04-25T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:23:37ZLexisNexisCBS MORNINGS PLUS9:00 AM ESTHamdi UlukayaNEWSInternational042501cb.408Russian General Killed in Car Bomb; Trump Rebukes Putin After Deadly Attack on Ukraine; Mourners Remember the Life & Legacy of Francis; Pope`s Legacy & Funeral Services Details; Teen Accused of Starting Massive NJ Wildfire; Harry & Meghan Spread Warning for Kids Online; The Scoop on the Yogurt Industry & Changing Policy; Vlad`s Top Five Ben Affleck Movies; Sharing The Stories Of Those Lost In History, CBSTony Dokoupil, Adriana Diaz, Holly Williams, Ed O`Keefe, Seth Doane, Norah O`Donnell, Chris Livesay, Christina Fan, Leigh Kiniry, Vladimir Duthiers, Courtney Cole, Elizabeth Werner

A senior Russian military official was killed in a car explosion near Moscow on Friday, the Investigative Committee of Russia said. Officials said it has launched a murder investigation. A Russian drone struck an apartment building in a city in southeastern Ukraine, killing three people and injuring 10 others, officials said Friday, a day after President Trump rebuked Russia`s leader for a deadly missile and drone attack on Kyiv while Washington endeavors to stop the more than three-year war. Millions around the world are mourning the loss of Pope Francis after his death Monday. Pope Francis` funeral will be held Saturday. A total of 130 foreign delegations will be attending, including President Trump and former President Joe Biden. A 19-year-old faces arson charges related to a wildfire that has scorched more than 15,000 acres in Ocean County, New Jersey. Prince Harry, the Duke of Sussex, said "enough is not being done" about the harm social media can cause children, as he appeared at the unveiling of a memorial in New York City dedicated to young people he said have died because of it. Chobani CEO Hamdi Ulukaya breaks down why the yogurt boom is behind the company`s historic $1.2 billion investment despite declining milk consumption and economic uncertainty. Vladimir Duthiers joins CBS Mornings Plus to talk about his top movies this weekend, starting with "The Second Best Night of Your Life," and "The Accountant 2" and his top five Ben Affleck films, "Dazed and Confused," "Chasing Amy," "Gone Girl," "Good Will Hunting" and "Argo." Historical interpreter Joe Palumbo shares the powerful legacy of Caesar Robbins, an enslaved man who fought in the American Revolution and later returned home a free man.

(ANNOUNCEMENTS)

ADRIANA DIAZ: It`s finally Friday, April 25th, 2025.

TONY DOKOUPIL: Get ready for CBS MORNINGS PLUS.

ADRIANA DIAZ: The world prepares to say a final farewell to Pope Francis as global leaders gather in Rome. We have the latest.

WOMAN: I think we all feel a little lost because when you love someone that you lose, you feel lost.

TONY DOKOUPIL: With all the headlines about bringing manufacturing back to the U.S., one company is ahead of the curve. We`ll talk to the founder and CEO of Chobani about his big plans.

ADRIANA DIAZ: Then we have the incredible story of some of the American Revolution`s hidden heroes in today`s edition of CBS Village.

JOE PALUMBO: By the end of the war, we know that on the patriots` side, over 5,000 men of color served.

Are you ready?

MAN 1: Yeah.

TONY DOKOUPIL: Plus, our Vladimir Duthiers is getting you ready for the weekend with his latest and greatest pop culture picks.

CHUCKIE: You know what the best part of my day is? It`s for about ten seconds when I pull up to the curb to when I get to your door. Because I think maybe I`ll get up there and I`ll knock on the door and you won`t be there. No goodbye, no "see you later", no nothing. You just left.

ADRIANA DIAZ: So young.

TONY DOKOUPIL: So young, such a great movie. And they co-wrote that together.

ADRIANA DIAZ: They did. I am wondering if Armageddon will be on Vlad`s top movie list for Matt David --

TONY DOKOUPIL: Is it on yours?

ADRIANA DIAZ: Yeah, it is. It should be on yours, too.

All right, good morning. Thank you so much for joining us. We have a lot of breaking news from overnight, including this. CBS News has learned a top Russian military officer has been killed in an apparent car bomb just outside Moscow. Holly Williams is tracking the latest developments from London.

Holly, good morning. What do we know?

HOLLY WILLIAMS: Good morning, Adriana. Russian officials say that Lieutenant General Yaroslav Moskalik was killed by an explosive device rigged with shrapnel and placed inside a car just outside of Moscow this morning. Moskalik was a senior figure in the general staff of Russia`s military. Russian media is reporting that the device was detonated remotely as he walked past, though we cannot confirm that detail at this point.

Now, this comes as President Trump`s Special Envoy, Steve Witkoff, is in Moscow for talks with Vladimir Putin aimed at securing a ceasefire in Ukraine. It`s Witkoff`s fourth visit to Russia this year.

Another Russian general was killed by a bomb hidden inside an electric scooter in Moscow in December. And Ukrainian security sources later confirmed that Ukraine was behind that assassination.

Tony.

TONY DOKOUPIL: Holly, thank you very much. Appreciate it. And that is not the only breaking news from that part of the world. Overnight, there were new airstrikes in Ukraine that left multiple people dead. Ukraine says Russia fired more than 100 suicide drones at the region. Child and elderly woman, as well, are reported to be among the victims of this attack. And all of it despite President Trump`s call yesterday directly to Vladimir Putin to stop the bombing now.

Ed O`Keefe is at the White House for us. He`s following it.

Ed, good morning.

ED O`KEEFE: Well, good morning. It was a rare rebuke after another major attack on Ukraine`s capital, and it comes as President Trump is trying to get both sides to agree to a peace deal.

(Begin VT)

ED O`KEEFE (voiceover): With bombs dropping on Kyiv yet again this week, President Trump singled out Russian President Vladimir Putin on Thursday. Stop, he said. Let`s get the peace deal done. The criticism continued later in an Oval Office meeting with the Prime Minister of Norway.

DONALD TRUMP (R) (U.S. President): I wasn`t happy with it, and we`re in the midst of talking peace, and missiles were fired, and I was not happy with it.

WILLIAM TAYLOR (Former Ambassador U.S.Ukraine): Finally, President Trump is expressing the frustration that he must feel about President Putin.

ED O`KEEFE (voiceover): William Taylor once served as U.S. ambassador to Ukraine.

WILLIAM TAYLOR: We`ll see if it`s effective, but it is necessary for President Trump to lean on, put pressure on President Putin to come to the table.

ED O`KEEFE: Trump`s focus on Russia came after he singled out Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy the day before for comments pushing back on ceding Crimea to Russia that Trump considered inflammatory.

(VOLODYMYR ZELENSKYY SPEAKING IN FOREIGN LANGUAGE)

ED O`KEEFE (voiceover): The Ukrainian leader was in South Africa Thursday before cutting his trip short, and had previously been in London for meetings on the war, meetings that Secretary of State Marco Rubio decided to skip at the last minute. At the White House, President Trump was asked what concessions Russia has offered to get closer to peace.

DONALD TRUMP: Stopping the war, stopping taking the whole country, pretty big concession.

ED O`KEEFE (voiceover): But he balked at the idea that he`s not putting pressure on Putin.

DONALD TRUMP: You don`t know what pressure I`m putting on Russia. They`re dealing. You have no idea what pressure I`m putting on Russia. We`re putting a lot of pressure.

(End VT)

ED O`KEEFE: Now, President Trump and President Zelenskyy are both scheduled to attend the Pope`s funeral this weekend at the Vatican. Zelenskyy has said he`s hoping to be able to meet with Trump in Rome, if possible.

Guys, back to you.

ADRIANA DIAZ: All right, that would be critical. Ed, thank you so much.

Turning now to the Vatican, where people have one last day to pay their respects to Pope Francis before his funeral tomorrow. Here are pictures from St. Peter`s Basilica. The Vatican says about 150,000 people have visited the Pope`s coffin, including members of the Pope`s own family who came yesterday to see him.

Seth Doane is in Rome, where he`s been talking to some of the mourners.

Seth, good morning.

SETH DOANE: Good morning to you, Adriana. As the world prepares for Francis` funeral, tributes are coming in so many different forms. This one stood out to us because it embodies a key part of the Pope`s legacy.

(Begin VT)

SETH DOANE (voiceover): Pope Francis encouraged embracing those on the margins, asking churches to house migrants. This one in Rome doubles as a dormitory at night. In the pews at the special prayer service last evening was George Malky (sp?), a 29-year-old engineer and refugee from Syria. Hoping to study, he fled the civil war, leaving his parents behind.

SETH DOANE: What does Pope Francis mean to you inside?

GEORGE MALKY (sp?) (Refugee from Syria): Hope and peace.

SETH DOANE (voiceover): Malky came to Italy through one of the humanitarian corridors supported by the Catholic Aid Group in Sant`Egidio. He arrived last May.

SETH DOANE: How is it living in Italy?

GEORGE MALKY: It`s so nice. It gives you the feel like it`s your home.

SETH DOANE (voiceover): There are language classes, and the group helps with housing, visas, and finding a job.

GEORGE MALKY: The people here all are so friendly, maybe because his message to them.

SETH DOANE: You think Pope Francis` message made a difference here?

GEORGE MALKY: Yes, of course.

SETH DOANE: How much do you --

SETH DOANE (voiceover): Mario Marazziti is among Sant`Egidio`s founding partners. We asked what it might mean to lose Francis.

MARIO MARAZZITI (Sant`Egidio Community Spokesperson): I`m worried that the world can be without a powerful moral leadership in a time in which leaders do not seem to be so focused on common good for the whole world. I`m worried that the world can be more alone.

(End VT)

SETH DOANE: George Malky, that Syrian refugee, told us he too hopes to get to pay his respects to Pope Francis. And Tony and Adriana, that group, Sant`Egidio, will be also taking part in Pope Francis` funeral tomorrow.

TONY DOKOUPIL: Seth, thank you very much. Appreciate it.

One of the visitors that our CBS cameras caught at St. Peter`s Basilica yesterday was this nun on your screen now from an order known as Little Sisters of Jesus. She was crying near the Pope. They had been friends, apparently, for decades. She felt a connection. Senior Correspondent Norah O`Donnell then spoke with one of the other nuns from that very same order.

(Begin VT)

NORAH O`DONNELL: How would you characterize his message?

WOMAN: I think that the emphasis on mercy was definitely a shift because society tells you you`re worth something for what you do. You`re only worth something for what you have. And the message of mercy that Pope Francis tried to share with us is that we`re loved. There`s nothing that we can do that would make God love us more, and there`s nothing that we can do that would make him love us less.

(End VT)

TONY DOKOUPIL: And Norah O`Donnell joins us once again. She`s, of course, been leading our coverage from Rome all week long, doing such a powerful job. Norah, good morning again. That interview calls to mind the question of the broader view that Francis had of the role of women in the church. What was it?

NORAH O`DONNELL: Yeah, good morning to you, Tony. You know, actually, days before the Holy Father`s death, he said, when women are in charge, things work. Well, he did elevate about a dozen women to top roles at the Vatican.

But remember, notably in our interview last year, he ruled out the idea of women becoming ordained as priests or deacons, even though I asked him about it several times. You know, we met a couple from Miami yesterday at the Basilica of St. Mary Major where the Pope will be buried. A one man named Jim Wilhelm, he was so emotional when I talked to him.

And he said, "Women are the backbone of the Catholic Church." He said, "Without women, our church would not survive." And I think that`s true. And that is why Pope Francis actually spent so much time with the nuns, because they are in many ways, too, also at the front lines of the church`s services for the poor.

TONY DOKOUPIL: And Norah, we are in the final hours now of the viewing. Mourners can stand at the foot of the Pope`s casket just for a little bit longer and then it`ll be sealed. What can we expect tomorrow at the funeral?

NORAH O`DONNELL: Yeah, and some of the biggest lines we have seen thus far, I think everybody realizes this is ending later today and they want an opportunity to say goodbye to the Pope. First tonight, there`s going to be this ancient ritual of sealing the coffin. That is done by Cardinal Kevin Farrell. He is the Camerlengo of the Roman Catholic Church. And that`s ahead of the papal funeral on Saturday morning.

The funeral mass begins at 4 a.m. Eastern time. Attending will be 130 foreign delegations. Those are the sirens when there`s an ambulance around here that you`re hearing. 50 heads of state, 10 monarchs, and that does include President Trump and former President Biden.

The mass is going to be about an hour and a half long. We just learn mostly in Latin, but there are going to be many other languages included. And of course we`re going to have it for you right here on CBS.

It`s going to be led by Cardinal Re. He is the Dean of the College of Cardinals. And then we will see this just incredible procession to the Basilica of Saint Mary Major where the Vatican says there will be a group of the poor and needy. They are going to be waiting outside to say a final farewell because as you know, Pope Francis dedicated his papacy to the poor.

Tony?

ADRIANA DIAZ: Yes. And incredible that those will be some of the last people to see the Pope. Norah, thank you so much.

It really takes a village. I want to just shout out some of the producers behind the scenes. Anna Matranga is our producer who works with the Vatican. She`s incredible. Julia Morris, Norah`s producer.

TONY DOKOUPIL: And stage manager, Patty.

ADRIANA DIAZ: Patty is there too. So we`re just so proud of our team out in Rome and we`ll be watching tomorrow. As millions around the world remember Pope Francis from afar, some who knew him up close are sharing their personal stories about him.

Chris Livesay brings us one of those stories from Rome. You don`t want to miss this.

(Begin VT)

CHRIS LIVESAY (voiceover): This may look like an ordinary store for glasses but 10 years ago, that all changed when Pope Francis dropped by.

Alessandro Spiezia, the owner of 58 years and his son Luca thought it was a once in a lifetime. Then this past summer, the phone rang.

LUCA SPIEZIA (Shop Owner): And the first time, it`s true, it`s fake, it`s a Pope.

ALESSANDRO SPIEZIA (Shop Owner) (through translator): Pope Francis needed to adjust his lenses. I told him, "you know we can come to you" and Francis said, "No, no, I don`t want to disturb you."

CHRIS LIVESAY (voiceover): So Francis came, again, but only wanted new lenses. The old frames worked just fine, Francis insisted. It was trademark Pope Francis, says his biographer, Austen Ivereigh.

AUSTEN IVEREIGH (Pope Francis` Biographer): I think he loved surprising people. I think that was the mischievous side of him. He loved to puncture pomposity and of course there`s a lot of that here.

CHRIS LIVESAY (voiceover): But not here, the store is so small it was once a storage closet in the church next door. Other Popes got their glasses here too but Francis was the first to come in person.

"The Pope revolutionized the thinking of the church," says Spiezia, but whoever is next, I hope he continues down the same path.

CHRIS LIVESAY: And that he comes here to get his glasses.

A. SPIEZIA: I don`t know.

L. SPIEZIA: I stay here, the shop, it`s here. It`s possible, do you need eyeglasses or sunglasses? It`s no problem.

(End VT)

CHRIS LIVESAY: The father and son told me that when people outside the shop saw the Pope inside, they thought that can`t be the Pope, they must be making a movie. But there were no cameras, just a man who wanted to be among the people, both in life and in death. The church where he`s going to be buried is some two miles outside the Vatican walls.

Back to you.

ADRIANA DIAZ: All right, Chris, thank you so much. We will of course bring you the funeral of Pope Francis in a CBS News special report. Coverage begins tomorrow at 4 a.m. Eastern. You can do it, set your alarms, you can wake up. That`s 1 a.m. Pacific, you too, West Coast. You can see it here on CBS and streaming on CBS News 24/7 and Paramount Plus.

TONY DOKOUPIL: Closer to home, we are learning more about how a devastating wildfire began in the state of New Jersey and it may not have been an accident. In fact, a 19-year-old has been arrested and is now facing arson charges. And it`s a fire that`s been very bad. It`s burned more than 15,000 acres. Luckily, it is about 50% contained at this point. Luck and a lot of hard work. Christina Fan from CBS News New York has more.

(Begin VT)

CHRISTINA FAN (voiceover): Smoke billowed into the air Thursday as crews in Southern New Jersey worked to halt the spread of this massive inferno.

MAN 2: A lot of the smoke has to do with the interior burning. This is a good thing.

CHRISTINA FAN (voiceover): Local law enforcement also announced the arrest of a teenager they allege started the blaze, 19-year-old Joseph Kling. Authorities say a joint investigation revealed Kling lit a bonfire using wooden pallets and left before it was fully extinguished. He now faces multiple arson charges.

BRADLEY BILLHIMER (Ocean County, NJ Prosecutor): We believe he is the person responsible for starting this fire and we intend to prosecute him to the fullest extent of the law.

CHRISTINA FAN (voiceover): The wildfire was first spotted Tuesday morning and spread quickly, prompting temporary evacuation orders for thousands of people. 87-year-old Patricia A Oravetz is among those happy to be back home.

PATRICIA ORAVETZ (Ocean County Resident): It was scary. I mean, the flames were very high and very bright and all different colors.

CHRISTINA FAN (voiceover): According to the chief of the New Jersey Forest Fire Service, there have been more than twice as many fires in the state so far this year than at the same point last year.

MAN 2: Once a fire like that gets established, there`s no actual catching it.

(End VT)

CHRISTINA FAN: Joseph Kling, who authorities accuse of starting this wildfire, will remain in Ocean County Jail until his next court appearance on Tuesday.

Back to you in studio.

ADRIANA DIAZ: Thank you, Christina. Wow, look at that background.

All right, moving on. Prince Harry and Meghan unveiled a new memorial in New York this week, dedicated to children who have died due to the harm they`ve experienced online. It is a cause close to their hearts, as they expressed in an interview after the event. Leigh Kiniry has more.

Leigh, good morning.

LEIGH KINIRY: Good morning. Prince Harry has said social media harm is a growing crisis that`s quietly taking our children, and he accused those with power of failing to act.

Now, the royals joined grieving families at the Lost Screen installation in New York City. It`s open for just 24 hours. They display 50 light boxes that resemble phones, each with a photo of a child, a child whose life online led to an untimely death.

Now, Prince Harry spoke to the BBC off camera at the vigil.

(Begin VT)

PRINCE HARRY: Life is better off of social media. I say that as a parent and I say that as someone who has spoken to many of kids here tonight who are on social media because they`ve lost a brother or a sister to social media. But clearly, enough is not -- enough is not being done.

(End VT)

LEIGH KINIRY: So what can be done? Many of those parents, part of a support group started by Harry and Meghan, protested outside Meta offices yesterday, demanding better regulation on their platforms. Meta have said they have significantly changed Instagram already with teen accounts to address some of those concerns, and governments around the world, like here in the UK, are legislating to force companies like Meta to protect children from content that encourages self-harm and suicide.

In the U.S., however, the Kids Online Safety Act has stalled in the House over concerns around censorship. Tony?

TONY DOKOUPIL: It`s a big issue, very concerning.

ADRIANA DIAZ: It`s a huge issue.

TONY DOKOUPIL: Yeah. Producer Leigh Kiniry, now Correspondent Leigh Kiniry, very nice to have you.

ADRIANA DIAZ: Love seeing you, Leigh.

LEIGH KINIRY: Thank you.

ADRIANA DIAZ: Leigh and I met like 13, 14 years ago in London when I was just starting at CBS and went to go visit the Bureau. She was so nice and showed me around. I was like entry-level.

TONY DOKOUPIL: We`re lucky to have her.

ADRIANA DIAZ: We are.

TONY DOKOUPIL: All right, coming up, lots of talk lately about avoiding tariffs by manufacturing products. Here in the U.S., one high-profile company is already doing exactly that, and they have decided to expand their efforts. We`re going to talk to the founder and CEO of a yogurt brand you have definitely tried, or at the very least heard of, Chobani.

Plus, our Mornings Memory takes us back to 1990 when our view of the universe changed forever. We`ll show you how. Stick around.

(ANNOUNCEMENTS)

ADRIANA DIAZ: During this time of economic uncertainty, many companies are rattled, worried, and some are even freezing hiring, as we`ve been reporting. But one business actually is hiring and is building what is said to be the biggest dairy plant in the country. That company is Chobani.

This week, they announced a $1.2 billion investment to build what will likely be the largest dairy factory in the United States. And with us now to talk about it is its CEO and Founder, Hamdi Ulukaya.

Hamdi, thank you so much for being here.

HAMDI ULUKAYA (Chobani CEO and Founder): Thanks for having me.

ADRIANA DIAZ: So this is a time, I mean, we keep hearing it, uncertainty, uncertainty, uncertainty. The markets are up and down. Investors are rattled. I know your company is not public yet, but companies are battening down the hatches and waiting to see before making big moves. But not you. Why make this expansion? Why take this risk at such an uncertain time?

HAMDI ULUKAYA: Yeah, we look at the world, of course, what`s happening in the world, Adriana, is real. And it`s a fact that it`s concerning from one dimension to another. But from the Chobani`s eye, I started 20 years ago in a small town Upstate New York, and I`ve seen a lot, you know, ups and downs and tough times.

But there are timeless truths, is that, you know, people want good food. People want to feed themselves and their children a bit food with the better ingredients. And that was the bet I made very, very long time ago. And we see, especially post-pandemic, this accelerated in a really, really dramatic way. So more and more people want simple food, high density nutrition food. And that growth is really pushing us to make decisions like this to invest.

TONY DOKOUPIL: And Chobani`s made in New York. Your hat says New York made. That`s --

HAMDI ULUKAYA: Yes, we made this hat for the event. Actually, we designed it.

ADRIANA DIAZ: Oh, from when you broke ground?

HAMDI ULUKAYA: Yes.

ADRIANA DIAZ: They just broke ground on the factory.

TONY DOKOUPIL: Nice. I missed it. You had the shovel and the dirt and the whole thing. That`s a beautiful thing. Oh, he made that bracelet.

HAMDI ULUKAYA: Yeah, for them.

TONY DOKOUPIL: You tell him, I don`t think it`s too shiny. I think it looks good.

ADRIANA DIAZ: They were saying on camera, guys.

HAMDI ULUKAYA: Baba in Turkish, and I have it.

ADRIANA DIAZ: What does it say in Turkish?

HAMDI ULUKAYA: Baba means dad.

ADRIANA DIAZ: Dad. Oh, lovely.

TONY DOKOUPIL: It`s eye-catching as it should be for an eye-catching announcement. So when you say made in the USA, it`s all made in the USA, the milk, all of it.

HAMDI ULUKAYA: Absolutely. Yogurt, fresh food, of course, that`s reason, another reason to be made in USA. We have a plant in South Ed when we started, and then we built a really big plant in Idaho. And then we come back to home to Rome, New York, which is only half an hour from where we started. Milk is local data farms. Fruit, most of the fruits are within the United States. We`d like to bring it more.

There are some products that come from overseas, but the most important thing that we get from overseas is the equipment to build the factory.

ADRIANA DIAZ: So how are you being affected by these tariffs?

HAMDI ULUKAYA: So that`s going to be effective. You know, that -- you know, you say $1.2 billion to build this plant, based on what kind of tax numbers or tariff numbers, it could be a lot bigger.

ADRIANA DIAZ: Because you would have to pay more, excuse me to jump in, but just to see how this all connects, tariffs on European equipment that you need would cost more to you because the tariffs would likely be passed on to you. Is that right?

HAMDI ULUKAYA: Right. So these high-speed fillers where you filled yogurt cups or the creamers or -- those are coming from Europe. And there`s not going to be, you know, short answer for those. So you`re going to pay more.

TONY DOKOUPIL: Yeah.

HAMDI ULUKAYA: That`s reality. The second one is labor. You know, we`re in Upstate New York, there`s a lot of projects that are happening. You know, buffalo bills are building a big stadium, requires a lot of people. And there`s semiconductor companies building more production. So those are the two things that we worry about, is what`s the tariff and can we find enough people to work.

ADRIANA DIAZ: Just staying on the tariffs for a moment, if you are going to pay more for the equipment that you need to make your yogurt, are you going to pass that along to the consumer? Will that be reflected in the price of your yogurt?

HAMDI ULUKAYA: You know, I have been very strongly opinionated. I even wrote an op-ed on this. During the pandemic and post-pandemic is this short answer to the, you know, covering the cost with going to prices is not the right thing to do.

Not good for business, not good for consumers. So I have been very strongly opinionated to not to pass the prices to the consumer. So we`ve been really, really steady on this. I look for long-term, you know, if I can afford to build it, which seems like we can, you know, internally, I look at this not something that I would pass on to the customers.

TONY DOKOUPIL: You have been outspoken in the past about efforts to hire immigrants and refugees. Every economist will say big picture long-term or even medium-term immigration is good for an economy, but some will say in the short-term it can affect wages for existing workers. How does that interaction work for you?

And also as this crackdown on immigration happens and there are fewer workers potentially, how do you think that will affect your ability to grow?

HAMDI ULUKAYA: I had my first contractor meetings yesterday at my office here in Soho. And we had two, three companies to come and be selecting. The number one topic is people. Do we have people to work to build this construction? Massive projects. And it`s a reality. It really is reality. And I hope Washington hears it and people hear it.

The second one is the farms. And if you look at farms, the vast majority of farm workers are immigrants. It`s the same thing in Idaho. It`s here in Upstate New York and between.

So between the farm workers and the workers for the construction, we need people. We need people who want to work. And those are refugees and immigrants. And of course, you have to have the legal right to work. And those are the policy makers have to make those, make it available.

But I can see one thing can hurt dramatically is if we can`t find people, we cannot build these places and we cannot make this farm works. And that is going to affect the prices and inflation. So I hope that message goes on really, really clearly.

TONY DOKOUPIL: Next up, a CBS Village story out of Boston that uncovers some of the American Revolution`s hidden heroes. You`re watching CBS Mornings Plus.

(ANNOUNCEMENTS)

ADRIANA DIAZ: Doesn`t that bring you back to 70 -- 1776?

TONY DOKOUPIL: For 250 years from Lexington, Concord.

ADRIANA DIAZ: That`s right. Every week we bring you a story from CBS Village giving voice to all communities. And this morning, our Courtney Cole from CBS News, Boston shines a light on hidden figures from the American Revolution.

(Begin VT)

COURTNEY COLE (voice-over): When you Google the American Revolution, you`ll see images of soldiers like this. But what if I told you some of the patriots also looked like this?

JOE PALUMBO (Historical Interpreter): I think it`s super important for people to understand that at the time of the American Revolution, the multiracial society of black, indigenous, mixed race people were all here. So it was only natural when the revolution broke out that they all participated.

COURTNEY COLE (voice-over): Meet Joe Palumbo, a Concordian with a passion for history.

COURTNEY COLE: Where does your passion come from?

JOE PALUMBO: I grew up here and when you grow up in a little town like this, they just pound the history into your head. But unfortunately, no one taught me any of these stories. No one taught me we had enslaved men and women helping, living and conquering, fighting in the American Revolution - - Revolution and building this country.

COURTNEY COLE (voice-over): Palumbo`s official title is historical interpreter. He tells me black and indigenous men and women, both free and enslaved, participated in every single incident of the American Revolution.

JOE PALUMBO: By the end of the war, we know that on the patriot side, over 5,000 men of color served and many served on the British side as well. Because people were just figuring out what would be the best way to gain freedom and independence for themselves.

COURTNEY COLE (voice-over): Of those more than 5,000 men of color. Today, we`re going to introduce you to Cesar Robbins. Enslaved at birth in nearby Chelmsford, Massachusetts, Palumbo says Robins served on April 19th, 1775.

JOE PALUMBO: We know for sure he later enlisted and fought in Dorchester Heights in Boston, fought in Fort Ticonderoga. And then after the war, he comes back to Concord as a free man.

COURTNEY COLE (voice-over): When he comes back to Concord, he lives on the edge of town. And later, this home that we`re going to take you into is built for Robbins and his descendants.

JOE PALUMBO: After you.

COURTNEY COLE: Thank you. Talk about history coming to life. We get to come and take a look inside.

JOE PALUMBO: That`s right. That`s how -- that`s how, you know, history`s happening. I want to show you this room over here. It was built in 1823, and you`re actually standing on the original floorboards of the home. It was about a mile from here out in the woods in the area called Wakefield, because free black Concordians were certainly not welcome to live in center towns. But that, the next site`s the really interesting site.

COURTNEY COLE: Oh, we`ve got a family tree here.

JOE PALUMBO: Yes. So it just shows you how difficult it is to reconstruct the history of these various families.

COURTNEY COLE (voice-over): It`s on this side of the house that we learn about Caesar`s daughter, Susan, her husband Jack Garrison, and their daughter Ellen Garrison, who went on to become anti-slavery activist.

JOE PALUMBO: I can only imagine 10 years from now what stories we`ll be talking about that we don`t know now.

COURTNEY COLE: I know. As long as we have those people who keep digging --

JOE PALUMBO: Yeah.

COURTNEY COLE: -- who want to know more, which is why it`s so important that our viewers get to see this.

JOE PALUMBO: Yeah.

COURTNEY COLE: Because then it also maybe spurs someone who`s watching --

JOE PALUMBO: Yes. That`s right.

COURTNEY COLE: -- to do some more digging.

JOE PALUMBO: That`s right. It`s always there if you want to do the work.

COURTNEY COLE (voice-over): The next part of our journey takes us to the old North Bridge where the shot heard round the world was fired on April 19th, 1775. This same bridge also has ties back to Caesar Robbins.

JOE PALUMBO: That bridge got repaired after the American Revolution. When it was repaired, one of the men who worked on it that time was Caesar Robbins. And this time he was paid because he was a free man. So it shows you sort of the arc. That bridge symbolizes freedom.

COURTNEY COLE (voice-over): The hands of enslaved men helped build the bridge we celebrate freedom on.

COURTNEY COLE: What is it like when you get to tell people this and they`re -- and they`re hearing this part of history for the first time?

JOE PALUMBO: I -- I think the most common reaction I get is, why didn`t anyone tell me? I didn`t know. I wish I had known that. And then they go quickly to, who else can I tell? Who else should know about this?

(End VT)

urn:contentItem:69BB-9T01-JBSP-117C-00000-00Studies from Ulsan National Institute of Science and Technology (UNIST) Yield New Data on Satellites (A deep learning model using geostationary satellite data for forest fire detection with reduced detection latency)2023-10-06T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:23:37ZLexisNexisSATELLITESStudies from Ulsan National Institute of Science and Technology (UNIST) Yield New Data on Satellites (A deep learning model using geostationary satellite data for forest fire detection with reduced detection latency)


2023 OCT 06 (NewsRx) -- By a News Reporter-Staff News Editor at Defense & Aerospace Daily -- New research on satellites is the subject of a new report. According to news originating from the Ulsan National Institute of Science and Technology (UNIST) by NewsRx correspondents, research stated, "Although remote sensing of active fires is well-researched, their early detection has received less attention. Additionally, simple threshold approaches based on contextual statistical analysis suffer from generalization problems."


Financial supporters for this research include Korea Environmental Industry And Technology Institute; Korea Institute of Marine Science And Technology Promotion; National Research Foundation of Korea; National Institute of Forest Science; Ministry of Interior And Safety.
Our news reporters obtained a quote from the research from Ulsan National Institute of Science and Technology (UNIST): "Therefore, this study proposes a deep learning-based forest fire detection algorithm, with a focus on reducing detection latency, utilizing 10-min interval high temporal resolution Himawari-8 Advanced Himawari Imager. Random forest (RF) and convolutional neural network (CNN) were utilized for model development. The CNN model accurately reflected the contextual approach adopted in previous studies by learning information between adjacent matrices from an image. This study also investigates the contribution of temporal and spatial information to the two machine learning techniques by combining input features. Temporal and spatial factors contributed to the reduction in detection latency and false alarms, respectively, and forest fires could be most effectively detected using both types of information. The overall accuracy, precision, recall, and F1-score were 0.97, 0.89, 0.41, and 0.54, respectively, in the best scheme among the RF-based schemes and 0.98, 0.91, 0.63, and 0.74, respectively, in that among the CNN-based schemes. This indicated better performance of the CNN model for forest fire detection that is attributed to its spatial pattern training and data augmentation. The CNN model detected all test forest fires within an average of 12 min, and one case was detected 9 min earlier than the recording time. Moreover, the proposed model outperformed the recent operational satellite-based active fire detection algorithms."
According to the news editors, the research concluded: "Further spatial generality test results showed that the CNN model had reliable generality and was robust under varied environmental conditions. Overall, our results demonstrated the benefits of geostationary satellite-based remote sensing for forest fire monitoring."
For more information on this research see: A deep learning model using geostationary satellite data for forest fire detection with reduced detection latency. GIScience & Remote Sensing, 2022,59(1):2019-2035. The publisher for GIScience & Remote Sensing is Taylor & Francis Group.
A free version of this journal article is available at https://doi.org/10.1080/15481603.2022.2143872.
Our news journalists report that more information may be obtained by contacting Yoojin Kang, Ulsan National Institute of Science and Technology.
Keywords for this news article include: Ulsan National Institute of Science and Technology (UNIST), Remote Sensing, Satellites.

urn:contentItem:6D7K-H0Y1-JBSK-R185-00000-00Calif. fire agency employee arrested on suspicion of starting 5 blazes2024-09-23T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:23:37ZLexisNexisTODAY'S STORIESCalif. fire agency employee arrested on suspicion of starting 5 blazes

By Associated Press SAN FRANCISCO - A California Department of Forestry and Fire Protection employee was arrested Friday on suspicion he started five brush fires in Northern California in recent weeks, officials said. Robert Hernandez, 38, was arrested at the Howard Forest Fire Station in Healdsburg, California, on suspicion of arson to forest land, the state agency said in a statement. Hernandez is an apparatus engineer with the agency, which entails operating and maintaining fire engines and water tanks during emergency responses.

Neither Cal Fire nor the union representing Cal Fire employees would say Friday whether they know if he has retained an attorney. Cal Fire said Hernandez ignited the blazes while off duty between Aug. 14 and Sept. 15 in forest land near Geyserville, Healdsburg and Windsor. The blazes combined burned less than an acre thanks to the quick action of residents and firefighters, the agency said. "I am appalled to learn one of our employees would violate the public's trust and attempt to tarnish the tireless work of the 12,000 women and men of CAL FIRE," Cal Fire Director and Fire Chief Joe Tyler said in the statement. Ari Hirschfield, a Cal Fire spokesperson, said in an email that the agency would not answer further questions about the arrest. On Tuesday, a delivery driver pleaded not guilty to starting the massive Line Fire on Sept. 5. The blaze forced the evacuation of thousands of people east of Los Angeles, injured a firefighter and destroyed a home. Justin Wayne Halstenberg, 34, was charged with 11 arson-related crimes, court records show. Authorities said Halstenberg, of Norco, attempted to start three fires within an hour. Two of the blazes were extinguished by firefighters and a good Samaritan, and a third became the Line Fire, which has charred 61 square miles in the San Bernardino mountains. It was 53 percent contained Friday. In July, a man was arrested on suspicion of starting the Park Fire in Northern California by pushing a burning car into a gully. Ronnie Dean Stout was charged with felony arson of an inhabited structure or property. He pleaded not guilty.

urn:contentItem:6D3F-3GD1-F06S-P02C-00000-00Rocket Lab Unveils 53rd Electron Mission, Implements Another 5 Satellites for Kineis2024-10-01T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:23:37ZLexisNexisRocket Lab Unveils 53rd Electron Mission, Implements Another 5 Satellites for Kineis

Rocket Lab USA, a company focusing on launch services and space systems, recently successfully launched its 53rd Electron mission and deployed five satellites to Low Earth Orbit for French Internet-of-Things (IoT) company Kineis.

The company said the 'Kineis Killed the RadIOT Star' lifted off from Rocket Lab Launch Complex 1 in Mahia, New Zealand, at 11:01 a.m. on 21 September NZST (23:01, 20 September UTC), successfully deploying five satellites to a 643 km orbit. The mission was the second of five dedicated Electron launches for Kineis, a company backed by private and public investors including the French government's space agency CNES (Centre National d'Etudes Spatiales) and CLS (Collecte Localisation Satellites), an international space-based solutions provider, to improve global IoT connectivity. The Kineis constellation is designed to make it possible to connect and locate any connected object anywhere in the world, enabling data transmission to users in near-real time, at low bit rates and with very low energy consumption. By enabling internet connection to the Earth's most remote locations, Kineis constellation can support forest fire detection, water resource management, infrastructure and energy network monitoring, transport and logistics tracking, and much more.

Rocket Lab founder and CEO Sir Peter Beck said: "Today's successful launch marks another milestone for Rocket Lab as we continue to enable innovative companies like Kineis to push the boundaries of global IoT connectivity. With each mission, we are bringing the world closer together, allowing vital data to be transmitted from the remotest corners of the Earth."

Across 53 launches Rocket Lab has now deployed 197 satellites for a diverse range of customers and missions, including NASA missions to the Moon, the National Reconnaissance Office and Space Force missions supporting national security and defense, scientific research to combat climate change, and commercial constellations providing vital data and services to millions of people on Earth.

Rocket Lab is an end-to-end space company with an established track record of mission success.

Launch webcast:

https://www.youtube.com/live/beVTGh_PrA0

More information and complete details:

www.rocketlabusa.com

((Comments on this story may be sent to newsdesk@closeupmedia.com))

urn:contentItem:69HF-M1M1-JBSP-11H8-00000-00New Remote Sensing Research Reported from Central University of Haryana [Integrated Spatial Analysis of Forest Fire Susceptibility in the Indian Western Himalayas (IWH) Using Remote Sensing and GIS-Based Fuzzy AHP Approach]2023-10-30T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:23:37ZLexisNexisTECHNOLOGY - REMOTE SENSINGNew Remote Sensing Research Reported from Central University of Haryana [Integrated Spatial Analysis of Forest Fire Susceptibility in the Indian Western Himalayas (IWH) Using Remote Sensing and GIS-Based Fuzzy AHP Approach]


2023 OCT 30 (NewsRx) -- By a News Reporter-Staff News Editor at Tech Daily News -- Data detailed on remote sensing have been presented. According to news originating from Haryana, India, by NewsRx correspondents, research stated, "Forest fires have significant impacts on economies, cultures, and ecologies worldwide. Developing predictive models for forest fire probability is crucial for preventing and managing these fires."


Financial supporters for this research include Grant-in-aid For Scientific Research.
Our news correspondents obtained a quote from the research from Central University of Haryana: "Such models contribute to reducing losses and the frequency of forest fires by informing prevention efforts effectively. The objective of this study was to assess and map the forest fire susceptibility (FFS) in the Indian Western Himalayas (IWH) region by employing a GIS-based fuzzy analytic hierarchy process (Fuzzy-AHP) technique, and to evaluate the FFS based on forest type and at district level in the states of Jammu and Kashmir, Himachal Pradesh, and Uttarakhand. Seventeen potential indicators were chosen for the vulnerability assessment of the IWH region to forest fires. These indicators encompassed physiographic factors, meteorological factors, and anthropogenic factors that significantly affect the susceptibility to fire in the region. The significant factors in FFS mapping included FCR, temperature, and distance to settlement. An FFS zone map of the IWH region was generated and classified into five categories of very low, low, medium, high, and very high FFS. The analysis of FFS based on the forest type revealed that tropical moist deciduous forests have a significant vulnerability to forest fire, with 86.85% of its total area having very high FFS. At the district level, FFS was found to be high in sixteen districts and very high in seventeen districts, constituting 25.7% and 22.6% of the area of the IWH region. Particularly, Lahul and Spiti had 63.9% of their total area designated as having very low FSS, making it the district least vulnerable to forest fires, while Udham Singh Nagar had a high vulnerability with approximately 86% of its area classified as having very high FFS. ROC-AUC analysis, which provided an appreciable accuracy of 79.9%, was used to assess the validity of the FFS map produced in the present study."
According to the news reporters, the research concluded: "Incorporating the FFS map into sustainable development planning will assist in devising a holistic strategy that harmonizes environmental conservation, community safety, and economic advancement. This approach can empower decision makers and relevant stakeholders to take more proactive and informed actions, promoting resilience and enhancing long-term well-being."
For more information on this research see: Integrated Spatial Analysis of Forest Fire Susceptibility in the Indian Western Himalayas (IWH) Using Remote Sensing and GIS-Based Fuzzy AHP Approach. Remote Sensing, 2023,15(4701):4701. (Remote Sensing - http://www.mdpi.com/journal/remotesensing/). The publisher for Remote Sensing is MDPI AG.
A free version of this journal article is available at https://doi.org/10.3390/rs15194701.
Our news editors report that more information may be obtained by contacting Pragya, Department of Geography, School of Basic Sciences, Central University of Haryana, Mahendragarh 123031, Haryana, India. Additional authors for this research include Manish Kumar, Akash Tiwari, Syed Irtiza Majid, Sourav Bhadwal, Netrananda Sahu, Naresh Kumar Verma, Dinesh Kumar Tripathi, Ram Avtar.
Keywords for this news article include: Central University of Haryana, Haryana, India, Asia, Remote Sensing, Technology.

urn:contentItem:68T0-CWS1-JBSP-10XG-00000-00Studies from Jamia Millia Islamia Yield New Information about Machine Learning (Forest Fire Susceptibility Mapping With Sensitivity and Uncertainty Analysis Using Machine Learning and Deep Learning Algorithms)2023-07-26T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:23:37ZLexisNexisMACHINE LEARNINGStudies from Jamia Millia Islamia Yield New Information about Machine Learning (Forest Fire Susceptibility Mapping With Sensitivity and Uncertainty Analysis Using Machine Learning and Deep Learning Algorithms)


2023 JUL 26 (NewsRx) -- By a News Reporter-Staff News Editor at Network Daily News -- Investigators discuss new findings in Machine Learning. According to news reporting out of New Delhi, India, by NewsRx editors, research stated, "In the hilly region of the Western Himalayas, forest fires play a crucial role in forest destruction and biodiversity loss. Therefore, addressing the problem of forest fires is an immediate priority to mitigate the impact of forest fires."


Financial support for this research came from Deanship of Scientific Research.
Our news journalists obtained a quote from the research from Jamia Millia Islamia, "Therefore, the objective of this research is to assess and map the susceptibility zones of forest fire in the hilly state of Uttarakhand using geospatial techniques and machine learning algorithms (MLA) and deep Learning based sensitivity and uncertainty analysis of the forest fire ignition parameters. Thirteen forest fire ignition parameters were used to map forest fire susceptibility. Further, we used five distinct MLAs, including arti-ficial neural networks (ANN), random forest (RF), logistic regression (LR), support vector machine (SVM) and an ensemble machine learning model. The generated models were validated using the receiver operating characteristic (ROC). The result shows that the 'very high'and 'high'zones for forest fires cover almost 55% of the total area of Uttarakhand. Validation of the models used indicated that all models produced most significant results. The ensemble machine learning had the highest accuracy (AUC = 0.977), followed by RF (0.973) and ANN (0.972). In addition, a Deep Neural Networks (DNN) based sensitivity approach is proposed to perform sensitivity and uncertainty analysis of the ignition parameters. For this, we have selected the best predictive model (Ensemble Machine Learning) to evaluate the sensitivity and uncertainty analysis. The sensitivity analysis shows that evapotranspiration has the highly influencing param-eter to forest fires, followed by annual rainfall, wind speed, distance to agriculture, distance to tourist spots, distance to built-up and distance to road. However, aspect, temperature and distance to religious centers have less influence on susceptibility to forest fires in this study area. This study is unique because it provides new insights into the construction of an ensemble machine learning model and the integration of DNN-based sensitivity and uncertainty for robust and scientific modelling of forest fire susceptibility. The contribution of parameters demonstrates a novel approach in understanding the impact of a single parameter sample on forest fire susceptibility, which will help in developing prevention strategies."
According to the news editors, the research concluded: "A similar approach may be used in other parts of the world with similar natural and anthro-pogenic conditions for mapping forest fire susceptibility. & COPY; 2023 COSPAR. ."
This research has been peer-reviewed.
For more information on this research see: Forest Fire Susceptibility Mapping With Sensitivity and Uncertainty Analysis Using Machine Learning and Deep Learning Algorithms. urn:contentItem:6DBR-S3H1-JC11-1494-00000-00Sen. Tester Resolution to Designate Mann Gulch Memorial Tribute Day Approved by Senate2024-11-05T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:23:37ZLexisNexisSen. Tester Resolution to Designate Mann Gulch Memorial Tribute Day Approved by Senateby MYRA TUGADE, Targeted News ServiceWASHINGTON

WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 -- Sen. Jon Tester, D-Mont., introduced a resolution on Aug. 1, 2024. The text of the resolution was released on Nov. 4.

S. Res. 798. A resolution commemorating the 75th Anniversary of the Mann Gulch fire by designating August 5, 2024, as "Mann Gulch Memorial Tribute Day"; considered and agreed to.

The resolution is cosponsored by Sens. Steve Daines, R-Mont., and Thom Tillis, R-N.C.

* * *

Commemorating the 75th Anniversary of the Mann Gulch fire by designating August 5, 2024, as "Mann Gulch Memorial Tribute Day".

Whereas, on August 5, 1949, the United States was shocked by a wildland fire-fighting tragedy in which 12 United States Forest Service smokejumpers and 1 district fire guard, a former smokejumper, tragically died when they were overtaken by a raging Mann Gulch forest fire in the Helena National Forest;

Whereas the smokejumpers answered a routine fire call from their base in Missoula, Montana, and after successfully landing by parachutes near the fire and beginning the process to contain and extinguish it, they were trapped as the fire exploded beneath them;

Whereas 8 of the 13 men who lost their lives were United States military veterans who served with distinction in World War II;

Whereas Bob Salle, 1 of 3 smokejumpers who survived the fire stated on the occasion of the 50th Mann Gulch Anniversary Memorial, "It is time to rededicate ourselves to the memory of these fine young men and the lesson they best taught us, that wildfires are, and always will be, dangerous and we must respect its potential to put a fire fighter in harm's way. Life is precious--and for some very short";

Whereas on the 75th Anniversary of this tragedy the Helena-Lewis and Clark National Forest and the National Smokejumpers Association will honor the memory of these young men by organizing memorial tribute activities--

(1) in Helena, Montana;

(2) at Mann Gulch; and

(3) at each of the 13 individual gravesites across the United States in Montana, New York, Massachusetts, Pennsylvania, Tennessee, North Carolina, and California;

Whereas this tragedy resulted in improved training, safety equipment, and fire-fighting strategies and the development of scientific research in fire behavior; and

Whereas, in the words of a sister of one of the Mann Gulch fatalities, "You think back, and you just wish, you hope that these men are not completely forgotten": Now, therefore, be it

Resolved, That the Senate--

(1) on the occasion of the 75th Anniversary of the Mann Gulch fire, honors the memory of Joseph Sylvia, Robert Bennet, Marvin Sherman, Silas R. Thompson, Stanley Reba, Newton Thompson, Leonard Piper, Davide Navon, Phillip McVey, Henry Thol, James Harrison, Eldon Diettert, and William Hellman who died in service to their country protecting our national resources;

(2) expresses heartfelt appreciation to all current men and women who fight wildfires today across the United States; and

(3) proclaims that August 5, 2024, be designated as "Mann Gulch Memorial Tribute Day".

urn:contentItem:6D99-8C61-JDGB-0532-00000-00Wildfire burns through forest in southern Greece, killing 22024-10-01T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:23:37ZLexisNexisTODAY'S STORIESWildfire burns through forest in southern Greece, killing 2

By Associated Press ATHENS, Greece - Two people died overnight in a large wildfire burning through forestland in Greece near a seaside resort in the country's south, authorities said Monday. The fire service said about 350 firefighters, assisted by 18 water-dropping aircraft, were battling the blaze near Xylokastro in the Peloponnese region. While the initial large front was put out, scattered flare-ups continued to burn, forcing evacuation orders for three villages Monday.

Earlier, half a dozen villages were ordered evacuated overnight as a precaution after the blaze broke out Sunday. There was no threat to Xylokastro. The flames were fanned by very strong winds blowing through forests left tinder-dry by a warm spring and hot summer, attributed to climate change. Civil protection officials warned that several parts of the country, including Rhodes and other southeastern Aegean Sea islands, would face a high risk of wildfires Tuesday. Authorities said the two dead men were believed to be residents who were declared missing late Sunday. No one else was reported missing. There were no immediate reports of burned homes in the affected area, located some 93 miles southwest of Greece's capital, Athens. Firefighters assisted by five water-dropping aircraft were also battling a forest fire that broke out Monday farther south, near Xerokambi in the central Peloponnese. Another wildfire near Andravida, in the western Peloponnese, was also brought under control Monday, but firefighters remained on alert. Greece, like other southern European countries, is plagued by destructive wildfires every summer that have been exacerbated by global warming. Over the past few months, authorities have had to cope with more than 4,500 wildfires in countryside left parched by a protracted drought and early summer heat waves, in what was considered the most dangerous fire season in two decades. A big investment in extra water-bombing aircraft, warning drones and other equipment have enabled firefighters to extinguish most blazes shortly after they broke out. However, in August, a ferocious wildfire swept through the mountains north of Athens, destroying scores of homes and killing one person. Still, authorities say this summer's expanses that have been burned are about 25 percent less in size than the annual average of the past 20 years.

urn:contentItem:6D6N-91D1-JCMC-W1S1-00000-00Lula sends to Congress bill that increases penalties for environmental crimes2024-10-16T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:23:37ZLexisNexisLula sends to Congress bill that increases penalties for environmental crimes

President Lula signed on Tuesday a bill that increases penalties against environmental crimes. The text has been prepared for weeks by the ministries of justice and environment amidst pressures against the government due to large forest fires that have plagued the country in recent months.

At a ceremony at the Planalto Palace, President Lula stated that the text will serve to “be tougher on people who do not respect environmental issues, laws, and what is essential for their own survival, which is maintaining a planet with air so we can breathe decently.”

He stated that the government will work to have the bill analyzed urgently in the Lower House and Senate. Congressman Patrus Ananias will be the rapporteur in the Lower House.

“This country is just showing that from now on we will not tolerate environmental crime. People will have to be severely punished,” he said.

The text increases the minimum and maximum penalties for environmental crimes, modifying 17 articles of Law No. 9605 of 1998, the Environmental Crimes Act. It also begins to consider climate damage and impacted ecosystem services in the fines imposed by the judiciary for this type of crime.

Furthermore, the initial penalty for several crimes is now imprisonment instead of detention, which means it starts to be served in a closed regime, according to Justice Minister Ricardo Lewandowski.

In the case of the crime of causing a forest fire, for example, the penalty increases from two to four years of imprisonment to three to six years of imprisonment, in addition to the fine already provided.

“These relatively lenient penalties primarily allowed for the prescription of crimes. They permitted either the suspension of the process, a plea bargain, or conditional release,” said the minister, speaking at the ceremony. “Of the 850,000 incarcerated individuals in Brazil, only 350 are imprisoned across the country for environmental crimes. This is not acceptable, given the enormous harmful potential of this very serious crime.”

Lewandowski stated that the text sent by the government represents a “systematization” of all the projects that were under discussion in Congress. It was attached to a bill by Senator Davi Alcolumbre, the likely future president of the Senate.

Also present at the ceremony, Environment Minister Marina Silva stated that deterrence is important in combating environmental offenses.

“Because it’s better to deter than to act on the crime when it’s already happening. And in this sense, increasing the penalty is certainly one way to create this deterrence,” she said.

(Essa publicação é parte integrante do jornal Valor Econômico e se sujeita aos termos de uso do site.)

urn:contentItem:6DMN-N5B1-JBTP-M1Y4-00000-00All Aboard: the Magic Valley Railroaders prepare for their Christmas train show2024-12-12T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:23:37ZLexisNexisSTATE AND REGIONAL NEWSAll Aboard: the Magic Valley Railroaders prepare for their Christmas train showMELANIE RIVERA-CORTEZThe Times-News, Twin Falls, Idaho

The Magic Valley Model Railroaders

Marvin Barnes, with the Magic Valley Model Railroaders, shows off a train set Monday, Dec. 9, 2024, at the Twin Falls County Fairgrounds in Filer.

FILER — During much of the year, the Twin Falls County Fairgrounds are empty. Inside of Building 16, however, the Magic Valley Railroaders help you punch your ticket to an interactive and educational learning experience.

The Magic Valley Railroaders are inspired by model railroading which involves creating a miniature version of a railroad transportation system.

The group works with train models from the smaller N scale to the larger G scale. The scale of a model is the relative size in proportion to the real thing. An N scale is 1/160 of its real life counter part, meaning that it would take 160 of them lined up to match the length of the real life model.

The club also owns several pieces of rolling stock including locomotives.

The Magic Valley Railroaders also build landscapes for their model trains to travel over. While most members help build buildings or people, Kathy Barnes helps by hand painting most of the landscapes.

“Kathy goes to work with a knife set in the middle of the floor, creates a big mess and paints them, puts the trees on them,” Kathy Barnes’ husband, Marvin Barnes, said.

The Magic Valley Model Railroaders

Marvin Barnes, a Magic Valley Model Railroader, talks about model train scales Monday, Dec. 9, 2024, at the Twin Falls County Fairgrounds in Filer.

This year, the group has spent almost 3,500 hours creating and maintaining various landscapes. Last year, members logged in almost 4,500 hours.

Marvin Barnes said that often times club members buy buildings — costing about $90 — to add to the scenery.

Club president, Randy Geisick, builds sets on the N scale. He often times uses paper to make houses and cabins that help create a more immersive experience.

“I’ve put little foam blocks and glued the paper to the blocks,” he said.

Geisick began his model train empire in 1974 before it all went into boxes in his mom’s basement. He moved from Colorado to California never thinking about his trains.

It wasn’t until about six years ago that he took a trip to Colorado and decided to move his trains to California before ultimately moving to Idaho.

Once he found the Railroaders, Geisick knew it was an instant fit for him.

“I would have been at home trying to do something in my garage,” he said, with “no friends, nobody understanding what the heck I was doing.”

The group has also created set timers that allow visitors to experience an interactive display. In one of the sets, visitors can push a button that will turn on a small red light, meant to signify fire, and in a few seconds smoke will show.

The Magic Valley Model Railroaders

Marvin Barnes, with the Magic Valley Model Railroaders, points out a forest fire they have incorporated into the landscape Monday, Dec. 9, 2024, at the Twin Falls County Fairgrounds in Filer.

“It’s interactive, so people can come out and they can start this fire,” Marvin Barnes said.

The Magic Valley Railroaders Christmas Train Show is set for Dec. 4, from noon to 3 p.m. at the Twin Falls County Fairgrounds next to the Ag Pavilion on Main Street.

The group will also have their version of Santa Clause’s village with reindeer, including a red-nosed Rudolph, and Santa’s house on display.

There will be a chance for a photo opportunity with Santa Clause.

Along with prizes, the group will be giving children a small locomotive eraser the same size as an N scale train.

There will also be free hot chocolate and cookies. Bridge Street Coffee will be available for those who want coffee.

The event is free to attend but donations are accepted.

“The purpose of this Christmas show is to get (families) to enjoy time together,” Marvin Barnes said.

The railroad building is open during the fair and on Saturdays from noon until 2 p.m. at other times during the year.

For more information, visit the Magic Valley Railroaders website at www.mvmodelrailroaders.com or contact Marvin Barnes at 208-934-7787.

All aboard! Magic Valley Model Railroaders share their passion at fairgrounds

Model railroaders have been busy this year making expansions to the track layout at Twin Falls County Fairgrounds.

The Magic Valley Model Railroaders | PHOTOS

Marvin Barnes, with the Magic Valley Model Railroaders, talks about different model train scales Monday, Dec. 9, 2024, at the Twin Falls County Fairgrounds in Filer.

urn:contentItem:6F6D-XPP3-RRP9-94YM-00000-00Fire lookout towers find renewed purpose2024-12-12T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:23:37ZLexisNexisGUEST COLUMNPg. A4Fire lookout towers find renewed purposeZeke Lloyd Guest ColumnistCamas

Zeke Lloyd

Photo courtesy of Zeke Lloyd

Chuck Manning and Pete Kitts enter Northwest Lookout Tower.

There's a small wooden cabin at the top of Northwest Peak, a few miles from Montana's borders with Idaho and Canada, and Chuck Manning, 79, believes lookouts like this one deserve a second chance at being useful.


The fire lookout sits at about 7,700 feet above sea level and seems to be in good condition despite being abandoned since 1955, when the Forest Service last staffed the outpost.
Manning leads the Northwest Montana Lookout Association, a nonprofit group that supports government agencies in restoring and maintaining lookout towers around Kootenai and Flathead national forests.
The Forest Service began building fire-detection towers after the Great Fire of 1910, then added more after the Civilian Conservation Corps and other government agencies considered lookouts - particularly in the West - as New Deal investments.
The result: State and federal workers built close to 8,800 lookouts throughout all 50 states. But by 2024, only about three in 10 lookouts remained standing. Roughly 6,200 were burned, collapsed from neglect or became scrap wood.
Why did the towers - and their ever-vigilant occupants-lose their fire-spotting role? Mark Hufstetler is an architectural historian who works for the Forest Service as a fire lookout at Baptiste Lookout, near Hungry Horse, Montana. He said the use of fire lookouts started declining after World War II partly because of the widespread introduction of two-way radios. They improved the range and speed of the Forest Service's ability to respond to fires.
The more important reason, Hufstetler said, was the development of aviation aircraft as fire spotters. "And as the decades progressed, that became more and more common."
But Hufstetler, who has staffed several different lookout locations in the last seven years, believes a network of human watchers is still a vital asset.
"I interact with visitors and provide them with probably the most positive experience that they will have with any federal agency personnel," Hufstetler said. "People are always in a great mood, and we can transmit that enthusiasm into an understanding of what the agency does."
Hufstetler believes versatility is an even more fundamental value of human lookouts. In the past five months, Hufstetler was able to relay information about a missing hiker, and in a separate incident, a missing person, to state authorities within seconds.
"I've got my radio with me at all times; it's on all night," Hufstetler said. "So I'm always available if things happen."
As longer and more devastating wildfires seasons continue to challenge firefighters across remote areas of the Rocky Mountains, Hufstetler said his vantage point also offers an important perspective when crews fight wildland fires near his tower.
"The key to being a good lookout is to have an intimate knowledge of where you are and why things are happening the way that they are," he said.
To preserve and protect lookout towers, some agencies have turned to renting out the historic structures to campers. In Montana, it's become such a popular program that a reservation is needed as much as six months in advance.
"It's not a normal place to go to get away from things and live on the top of a mountain. Nobody else is around except birds and wildlife," Manning said. "That's their home. You're basically planting yourself into an environment where nature calls the shots."
Manning said he doesn't have to worry about whether the next generation will continue the work of maintaining these historical structures: "There will always be people with a passion for lookouts," Manning said, as he drove back toward Kalispell from Northwest Peak. He trusts that others will fall in love with these historic outposts, just as he did.
"There's nothing greater than having a cup of coffee on any of the lookouts that we're repairing," Manning said, "while watching the sunrise or the sunset."
Short lookout stays are managed by the Forest Service through the lookout rental program (tinyurl.com/59mfkzjp).
You can learn more about fire lookout preservation through the Forest Fire Lookout Association (firelookout.org/index.html) or the Northwest Montana Lookout Association (nwmt-ffla.org). To find out more about staying in a fire tower in Washington state, Washington Trails Magazine published a guide in 2022, which can be found online at wta.org/news/magazine/features/what-you-need-to-know-about-spending-the-night-in-a-fire-lookout
